title: Bikram Singh (lieutenant general)
text:
<a href="Lieutenant%20General%20%28India%29">Lieutenant General</a> Bikram Singh, <a href="Param%20Vishisht%20Seva%20Medal">PVSM</a> (4 July 1911 – 22 November 1963) was a <a href="General%20Officer">General Officer</a> in the <a href="Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a>. He was the <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">General Officer Commanding</a> <a href="XV%20Corps%20%28India%29">XV Corps</a> when he was killed in the <a href="1963%20Poonch%20Indian%20Air%20Force%20helicopter%20crash">1963 Poonch Indian Air Force helicopter crash</a>.
Early life and education.
Singh was born on 4 July 1911. He attended the <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales%20Royal%20Indian%20Military%20College">Prince of Wales Royal Indian Military College</a> at Dehradun. In 1930, he was selected to attend the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20Sandhurst">Royal Military Academy Sandhurst</a>.
Military career.
Early career.
Singh graduated from Sandhurst in 1933 and was commissioned as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> and placed in the unattached list of the Indian Army. Newly commissioned Indian officers were attached with a British unit before being sent to an Indian unit. He was attached with the <a href="Royal%20Berkshire%20Regiment">Royal Berkshire Regiment</a>. After an year's attachment, he was posted to the 6th Royal Battalion (Scinde), the <a href="13th%20Frontier%20Force%20Rifles">13th Frontier Force Rifles</a> which was stationed at <a href="Kohat">Kohat</a> in the <a href="North-West%20Frontier%20Province">North-West Frontier Province</a> (NWFP). Subsequently, the battalion moved to <a href="Razmak">Razmak</a> and join the <a href="Razmak%20Brigade">Razmak Brigade</a>. He spent three years in NWFP, till 1937, participating in multiple active operations.
World War II.
During the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in 1939, he was serving with his battalion. He moved with the battalion to <a href="North%20African%20campaign">North Africa</a> and took part in the <a href="Western%20Desert%20campaign">Western Desert campaign</a> and was present during the <a href="Siege%20of%20Tobruk">Siege of Tobruk</a>. He subsequently served in Iran and Irag during the <a href="Middle%20East%20campaigns">Middle East campaigns</a>. At the end of the war, he was selected to attend the <a href="Staff%20College%2C%20Quetta">Staff College, Quetta</a>. He graduated in 1946 and was appointed Deputy Assistant Quartermaster General (DAQMG) <a href="26th%20Indian%20Infantry%20Division">26th Indian Infantry Division</a> which was deployed in the <a href="far%20east">far east</a>.
Post-Independence.
In April 1947, he was promoted to the rank of <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> and appointed <a href="commanding%20officer">commanding officer</a> of the 4th battalion, the <a href="Rajput%20Regiment">Rajput Regiment</a> (4 RAJPUT). During the <a href="partition%20of%20India">partition of India</a>, civil disturbances and riots erupted across the country. He led his battalion in quelling these disturbances in <a href="Calcutta">Calcutta</a> and subsequently in <a href="Ranchi">Ranchi</a>. In October that year, he was promoted to <a href="Colonel%20%28India%29">Colonel</a>. In <a href="Kurukshetra">Kurukshetra</a>, the country's largest <a href="refugee%20camp">refugee camp</a> was set up. Singh was posted to the camp to help run it.
In February 1948, civilian authorities took over the administration of the refugee camp. Singh handed the camp over and was promoted to the rank of <a href="Brigadier%20%28India%29">brigadier</a>. He took command of an <a href="Brigade">infantry brigade</a> engaged in active operations in <a href="Jammu%20and%20Kashmir%20%28princely%20state%29">Jammu and Kashmir</a> during the <a href="Indo-Pakistani%20War%20of%201947-1948">Indo-Pakistani War of 1947-1948</a>. After the war, he commanded another infantry brigade in the Kashmir Valley. In December 1949, he was appointed commander of the 181 Independent brigade group in <a href="Undivided%20Assam">Assam</a>.
He has a long stint in Assam, commanding the brigade group for four years, till 1953. He was then appointed Brigadier in charge administration (Brig Adm) of the <a href="Eastern%20Command%20%28India%29">Eastern Command</a>. In 1954, the headquarters of the Eastern Command moved from Ranchi to <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a>. As the Brig Adm, Singh was responsible for the transfer of the HQ and oversaw its successful completion.
General officer.
In August 1955, Singh was promoted to the rank of <a href="Major%20general%20%28India%29">major general</a> and appointed <a href="General%20officer%20commanding">General officer commanding</a> an <a href="infantry%20division">infantry division</a>. He commanded the division for over two-and-a-half years which was based in <a href="Jammu%20and%20Kashmir%20%28state%29">Jammu and Kashmir</a>. He subsequently was appointed GOC Assam area, a static formation, which he commanded for a little over a year. In February 1959, he moved to Delhi having been appointed GOC Delhi & Rajasthan Area. As the GOC of the area, he oversaw the <a href="Army%20Day%20%28India%29">Army Day</a> and the <a href="Delhi%20Republic%20Day%20parade">Delhi Republic Day parade</a>s in 1960 and 1961. In June 1961, he was promoted to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20general%20%28India%29">lieutenant general</a> and appointed GOC <a href="XV%20Corps%20%28India%29">XV Corps</a>, headquartered at <a href="Srinagar">Srinagar</a>.
Death and legacy.
On 22 November 1963, Singh was killed when his helicopter crashed en route to <a href="Poonch%20%28town%29">Poonch</a>. In a great loss to the Indian Armed Forces, the crash claimed six distinguished officers. The officers who were on the helicopter apart from Singh were:
The news of the air crash came as a shock to the nation. A black-bordered extraordinary <a href="Gazette%20of%20India">Gazette of India</a> was issued on 23 November. The issue was raised in both houses of <a href="Parliament%20of%20India">Parliament of India</a> and addressed by the <a href="Minister%20of%20Defence%20%28India%29">Minister of Defence</a> <a href="Yashwantrao%20Chavan">Yashwantrao Chavan</a>. The <a href="Rajya%20Sabha">Rajya Sabha</a> observed one minute's silence as a mark of respect to the memory of the deceased and adjourned for the day. The <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defence%20%28India%29">Ministry of Defence</a>, the three service headquarters and all defence establishments in New Delhi were closed on 23 November as a mark of respect. All public events of the Defence Minister and Service Chiefs were also cancelled. The officers were laid to rest with full military honours. Singh was awarded the <a href="Param%20Vishisht%20Seva%20Medal">Param Vishisht Seva Medal</a> posthumously on 26 January 1964.
A memorial has been built at the site of the air crash, commemorating the names of the victims. The Indian Army organises an annual event to pay homage to them. An 'Akhand Path' is also organised by the people of Poonch and surrounding villages, as a mark of their love and affection towards the departed souls, every year to commemorate the tragic accident. A statue of Singh is installed in <a href="Jammu">Jammu</a> and a memorial in his ancestral village of Siana in <a href="Nawanshahr">Nawanshahr</a>. A library and a museum dedicated to him is also being constructed. The "Bikram Chowk" in Jammu is also named for the general. Two committees – the "Lieutenant General Bikram Singh Society" at Kahma village and the "Lieutenant General Bikram Singh Yadgaar Committee" in Jammu organise ceremonies, akhand paths, blood donation camps among other events to remember him.
